Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD's application of the reasonableness standard to review the RPD's credibility findings was legally correct
Application_Facts: The RAD relied heavily on the RPD's findings, used 'reasonableness' language, and did not conduct its own assessment; it assumed the RPD's findings were correct and placed the burden on the applicant to rebut them
Decision_Outcome: The RAD erred in law by failing to independently assess the evidence
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the RAD's decision
Court_Ruling: Court allowed judicial review and remitted the matter to the RAD for reconsideration by a different panel
Grounds_for_Claim: Credibility issues and lack of asylum claims in transit countries
Procedural_Issue: Standard of review applied by the RAD
Credibility_Assessment: RAD failed to conduct independent credibility assessment and deferred improperly to RPD

Application_Basis: Refugee claim dismissed due to credibility concerns
Relief_Sought: Allowance of judicial review and remittal for re-determination
Governing_Rule: The RAD must independently assess evidence rather than merely reviewing RPD decisions for reasonableness
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure by RAD to independently assess evidence
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remitted for re-determination
